message.content:
We begin by “translating” each statement into an arrow notation that shows “X is an ancestor of Y” (which is equivalent to “Y is a descendant of X”). For example, “Gary is Roy’s descendant” means that Roy is an ancestor of Gary.

Two key pieces of information are:

• Arthur appears in the statement “Arthur is Kimberly’s descendant.” This tells us: Kimberly → Arthur.

• Judith appears in the statement “Judith is Sara’s ancestor.” So we have: Judith → Sara.

Then, by using the other relationships we “chain‐up” the ancestors for both Arthur and for Judith. (Note that many of these clues connect the entire family.)

Working upward from Arthur:
1. Arthur is a descendant of Kimberly, so: Kimberly → Arthur.
2. Kimberly is given as a descendant of Denise, so: Denise → Kimberly.
3. We also have “Shirley is Denise’s ancestor” so: Shirley → Denise.
4. Then “Julie is the ancestor of Shirley” appears (since “Shirley is Julie’s descendant”), so: Julie → Shirley.
5. Next, “Brenda is the ancestor of Julie” (because “Julie is Brenda’s descendant”), so: Brenda → Julie.
6. “Brenda is connected to Albert” via “Brenda is Albert’s descendant” which gives: Albert → Brenda.
7. Then “Albert is noted through ‘Albert is Nancy’s descendant’” so: Nancy → Albert.
8. Next, “Kathryn is Nancy’s ancestor” gives: Kathryn → Nancy.
9. “Kathryn is also found as the descendant of Jonathan” (since “Kathryn is Jonathan’s descendant”) so: Jonathan → Kathryn.
10. Then, “Jonathan is, in turn, the descendant of Willie” (“Jonathan is Willie's descendant”) which gives: Willie → Jonathan.
11. “Willie is a descendant of Dorothy” (“Willie is Dorothy’s descendant”) so: Dorothy → Willie.
12. “Vincent is Dorothy’s ancestor” gives: Vincent → Dorothy.
13. “Vincent is then linked via ‘Vincent is Dennis’s descendant’” – meaning Dennis → Vincent.
14. Next, “Gregory is Dennis’s ancestor” yields: Gregory → Dennis.
15. “Gregory appears in ‘Gregory is Linda’s descendant’”, so: Linda → Gregory.
16. Finally, “David is Linda’s ancestor” gives: David → Linda.

Thus Arthur’s full ancestry chain (from the very top as we later see) is:
David → Linda → Gregory → Dennis → Vincent → Dorothy → Willie → Jonathan → Kathryn → Nancy → Albert → Brenda → Julie → Shirley → Denise → Kimberly → Arthur.

Now looking at Judith’s side:
1. Start with “Judith is Sara’s ancestor”: Judith → Sara.
2. Then “Sara is Harold’s ancestor”: Sara → Harold.
3. “Harold is Jacob’s ancestor”: Harold → Jacob.
4. “Amy is Jacob’s descendant” means Jacob → Amy.
5. “Amy is Jason’s ancestor”: Amy → Jason.
6. “Jason is Maria’s ancestor”: Jason → Maria.
7. “Stephen is Maria’s descendant”: Maria → Stephen.
8. “Stephen is also given as Sean’s ancestor”: Stephen → Sean.
9. “Sean is Kayla’s ancestor”: Sean → Kayla.
10. “Ronald is Kayla’s descendant”: Kayla → Ronald.
11. “Jessica is Ronald’s descendant”: Ronald → Jessica.
12. “Jessica is also the ancestor of Jesse”: Jessica → Jesse.
13. “John is Jesse’s descendant”: Jesse → John.
14. “John is given as the ancestor of Jose”: John → Jose.
15. “Brandon is Jose’s descendant”: Jose → Brandon.
16. “Amanda is Brandon’s descendant”: Brandon → Amanda.
17. “Christian is Amanda’s descendant”: Amanda → Christian.
18. “Christian is noted as the ancestor of Katherine”: Christian → Katherine.
19. “Ann is Katherine’s descendant”: Katherine → Ann.
20. “Ann appears as Bradley’s ancestor”: Ann → Bradley.
21. “Bradley is Sandra’s ancestor”: Bradley → Sandra.
22. “Susan is Sandra’s descendant”: Sandra → Susan.
23. “Susan is also described as Ryan’s ancestor”: Susan → Ryan.
24. “Madison is Ryan’s descendant”: Ryan → Madison.
25. “Frances is Madison’s descendant”: Madison → Frances.
26. “Frances is the ancestor of Edward”: Frances → Edward.
27. “Edward is Megan’s ancestor”: Edward → Megan.
28. “Megan is Doris’s ancestor”: Megan → Doris.
29. “Matthew is Doris’s descendant”: Doris → Matthew.
30. “Matthew is the ancestor of Christina”: Matthew → Christina.
31. “Christina is the ancestor of Anna”: Christina → Anna.
32. “Anna is the ancestor of Keith”: Anna → Keith.
33. “Andrea is Keith’s descendant”: Keith → Andrea.
34. “Andrea is the ancestor of Russell”: Andrea → Russell.
35. “Christopher is Russell’s descendant”: Russell → Christopher.
36. “Christopher is the ancestor of Cheryl”: Christopher → Cheryl.
37. “Cheryl is the ancestor of Roy”: Cheryl → Roy.
38. “Roy is linked to Gary by ‘Gary is Roy’s descendant’”: Roy → Gary.
39. “Alexander is Gary’s descendant”: Gary → Alexander.
40. “Cynthia is Alexander’s descendant”: Alexander → Cynthia.
41. “Diane is Cynthia’s descendant”: Cynthia → Diane.
42. “William is Diane’s descendant”: Diane → William.
43. “William is also said to be Nathan’s ancestor”: William → Nathan.
44. “Nathan is Eric’s ancestor”: Nathan → Eric.
45. “Douglas is Eric’s descendant”: Eric → Douglas.
46. “Peter is Douglas’s descendant”: Douglas → Peter.
47. “David is Peter’s descendant”: Peter → David.

Thus Judith’s full chain is:
Judith → Sara → Harold → Jacob → Amy → Jason → Maria → Stephen → Sean → Kayla → Ronald → Jessica → Jesse → John → Jose → Brandon → Amanda → Christian → Katherine → Ann → Bradley → Sandra → Susan → Ryan → Madison → Frances → Edward → Megan → Doris → Matthew → Christina → Anna → Keith → Andrea → Russell → Christopher → Cheryl → Roy → Gary → Alexander → Cynthia → Diane → William → Nathan → Eric → Douglas → Peter → David

Notice that the very last person in Judith’s chain is David. But David is also the top (earliest) ancestor in Arthur’s chain. Since Judith is an ancestor of David and David is an ancestor of Arthur, by the transitive property of lineage we see:

Judith → … → David → … → Arthur

That is, Judith is an ancestor of Arthur. Equivalently, Arthur is a descendant of Judith.

Thus the correct selection is:

<ANSWER>3</ANSWER>
